Isn't that more or less the purpose of the age penalty for species
that hav=
en't made progress in N generations?

On 11/10/05, Colin Green <cgreen@dsl.=
pipex.com> wrote:
> Here's an idea that's relatively easy to implement and =
experiment with -
> extinction events. I think I'm right in saying that in =
biological
> evolution mass extinction events are thought to give evolution=
 a bit of
> a kick. E.g. the cambrian explosion
> <http://en.wikipedia.org/=
wiki/Cambrian_explosion>. Then there's the
> argument about how far dinosau=
rs would have developed if they hadn't
> been zapped by a comet and that ma=
mmals (or some slug like ancestor of
> mammals anyhow) were able to fill in=
 the gap left behind, amongst other
> lifeforms.
>
> So all we need is some=
 routine that randomly similarly zaps (I believe
> that's the technical ter=
m) our populations/species every once in a
> while. You can do this automat=
ically if a search has stagnated for N
> generations ans/or hours, or just =
have some way of allowing the user to
> trigger an extinction manually. Wor=
th a try I reckon.
>
